"Everyone’s driving in a different direction!" – Benjamin

Benjamin was a capable leader with a strong team.

But instead of moving forward together, every department was steering toward its own destination—competing priorities, conflicting goals, and misaligned incentives.

At first, he thought the issue was a lack of communication.

But as he dug deeper, he realized the real problem: every team was optimizing for their own success instead of the company’s mission.

 “We need to hit our own targets first.” Teams prioritized individual KPIs over shared outcomes.
 “Other departments slow us down.” Silos formed as teams avoided external collaboration.
 “We can’t afford to change direction.” Past alignment efforts had felt disruptive and frustrating.
 “Leadership will step in if it’s important.” Teams waited for top-down mandates instead of proactively aligning.

Benjamin knew he had to shift the mindset from my team’s success to our company’s success.

Instead of demanding alignment, he created the right structure for it to happen naturally:
 A shared roadmap. Clear priorities so every department moved toward the same destination.
 Checkpoints along the way. Milestones and communication cadences to keep teams in sync.
 Cross-team incentives. Success was redefined as collective progress, not individual wins.

The result?

His team stopped pulling in different directions and started accelerating together.

Productivity soared, friction decreased, and Benjamin no longer felt like a referee in a game with no rules.

Is your team driving in different directions?

Alignment isn’t about forcing people to follow orders—it’s about making sure they want to move together.

With only 2 spots left in the Feb 6th vWorkshop, now’s the time to master the strategies that make alignment natural.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights, Benjamin! Fostering cross-functional alignment is key to driving collective success. Excited for the workshop! 🚀

Adam P. Boyd
postsData.content:
$15 an hour doing cold calls.
That's how I started. 
Karl Scheible (my mentor and ex-boss) offered me an internship (despite my MBA) making $15/hour doing cold calls.

He'd pay $100 per person if I "closed" them by getting them to attend our executive luncheons.

Plus, I'd get 20% of any retainer if he closed a deal.

Here I was, a fresh MBA, in a windowless room, calling CEOs from a book of lists.
Fridays were a relief.
Sundays were awful.
Mondays meant starting over, feeling like I sucked.

But I persisted.

(I hate being bad at things, so I just kept grinding)

Eventually, I got a bit lucky.

In-person meetings went better; people would actually talk to me and say they'd check out what we were doing.

I wasn't great at cold calling (I'm better now, but never mastered it).

I just refused to quit.

We closed some business, I made some money, which kept me going.

But really, it was Karl's patience and coaching that kept me in the game.

Eventually, he allowed me to begin training the professionals who attended our programs, and coaching the salespeople who were looking to apply the tools we gave them.

And then I went on to have a career in sales.

Who remembers their first sales gig? I’m a sucker for these types of starts.

Started learning nonverbal cues, asking open-ended questions getting plenty of no’s. I think we made five dollars an hour and the commissions were a small percentage of the wedges, bags, knock off golf balls, and clubs.

2024: A Year of Innovation and Growth at RepuGen 

At RepuGen, 2024 wasn’t just about keeping up with the trends, it was about creating them! From harnessing the power of AI to forging key partnerships, this year was all about empowering healthcare providers to succeed in the rapidly evolving digital landscape.

One of the biggest milestones for us was the introduction of Anonymous Patient Surveys. We wanted to give healthcare providers a way to build trust with their patients, so we focused on creating an environment where candid feedback could be shared without hesitation. This honest feedback is what helps healthcare providers improve and grow.

Another proud achievement was the launch of CommentWiz, our AI-powered tool designed to help healthcare providers gain smarter, more insightful feedback. It’s all about using the power of artificial intelligence to give providers a clearer understanding of patient sentiments and enabling them to make data-driven decisions.

On the partnership front, we took a major step forward by teaming up with Kalix. This collaboration has helped streamline patient care and provider workflows, ensuring smoother interactions for both patients and healthcare professionals.

It’s been an incredible year of unlocking insights into patient preferences, sharing essential industry knowledge, and connecting with thought leaders. And as we look ahead to 2025, we’re more excited than ever for what’s next.

I’m so proud of the strides we’ve made, and I can’t wait to continue this journey.

postsData.content:
Small actions, big impact. When it comes to climate change, many believe that only sweeping policies and large-scale initiatives can make a difference. But in reality, microactions—small, consistent choices made by individuals—hold immense power. From reducing single-use plastics to making conscious energy choices, these incremental steps create a ripple effect that influences communities and industries alike.

By adopting microactions, individuals contribute to a larger movement without feeling overwhelmed. Simple habits like choosing reusable bags, supporting sustainable brands, or reducing food waste add up over time. When multiplied across millions of people, these everyday decisions drive real change, shaping demand for greener products and pushing businesses to adopt sustainable practices.

The power of microactions lies in their accessibility. No grand gestures are required—just consistent, mindful choices that align with a more sustainable future. When people recognize that their daily behaviors matter, they become part of a collective force that challenges the status quo. Climate action isn’t reserved for policymakers or corporations; it begins with the small, intentional steps taken every day.

postsData.name:
Radha Vyas
Radha Vyas
postsData.content:
When my business collapsed, I felt so much shame. 

COVID caused us to lose everything overnight. 

And all I could think was:

What do I tell the team?
What do I tell our customers?
What do I tell my family & friends?

It felt like I’d let everyone down.

The weight of it was crushing.

For weeks, I wrestled with these questions. I wanted to hide, to bury the failure, and hope no one noticed.

But hiding wasn’t an option.

Instead, I chose transparency.

 I spoke to the team with honesty, treating them with dignity even as we faced the impossible.

 I reached out to customers, owning what had happened and thanking them for their support.

 I told my family and friends, despite the discomfort and vulnerability it took.

I didn't sugarcoat a thing.

And do you know what happened?

People showed up.

→The team thanked us for how we handled the situation. →Customers were kind and encouraged us to rebuild.
→Friends and family became our pillars of strength.

In hindsight, transparency did more than rebuild trust...

It lay a foundation to start over, stronger than before.

When we started rebuilding the business:

 Former team members returned.
 Suppliers wanted to work with us again.
 Customers were excited to travel with us again.

The truth is, failure doesn’t define you.

How you handle it does.

Owning setbacks paves the way for a strong comeback.

And that transparency earns respect, trust and keeps doors open for opportunities you can’t see yet.

Have you ever had to own a failure?

️ Repost if this resonates.

_

 I'm, CEO & Co-Founder of, connecting solo travelers on life-changing social adventures.

Follow for daily posts on the journey!

comments.commentText: Failure doesn’t define us, how we face it does. Embracing transparency not only rebuilds trust, but it also opens unexpected doors for growth and support.Radha Vyas

What was your original career path and how did you end up in the cyber security field?

I spent many years working in the entertainment industry with Chris Tarrant, the host of “Who Wants to Be a Millionaire” in the UK, but I took the decision to join my first husband’s cyber security software development company in 2009. I love the fact that everything in cyber security makes a huge difference. If I can help to stop businesses of any size from getting breached or suffering a cyber-attack through raising awareness of the importance of cyber security and of the growing cyber threat, I will be happy.

 Name a book/movie that has inspired you. Anything specific to cyber security that you would recommend?

I am a HUGE fan of Queen and grew up with the band from the moment I was born. 𝐘𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐌𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐬𝐞𝐭 𝐈𝐬 𝐄𝐢𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐫 𝐘𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐆𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐬𝐭 𝐀𝐬𝐬𝐞𝐭 𝐨𝐫 𝐘𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐁𝐢𝐠𝐠𝐞𝐬𝐭 𝐎𝐛𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐜𝐥𝐞

Tom Brady threw a pick-six on his first college pass.
He was drafted 199th overall.
His first NFL season? Four games with more interceptions than touchdowns.

Most people would have taken those moments as proof they weren’t good enough. But Brady didn’t.

Why?

Because he mastered his mindset.

And that changed everything.

Your belief system dictates your reality. If you believe you’re limited—whether in your career, business, or personal life—your actions will reinforce that belief.

For example:

 The ambitious professional who tells himself he’s “not leadership material” never steps up—and never gets promoted.
 The entrepreneur who believes “nobody is buying right now” pulls back on marketing—and watches sales dry up.

It’s a self-fulfilling prophecy.

But the flip side is also true:

 The leader who believes in his ability to solve problems takes bold action and earns respect.
 The athlete who trusts in his training keeps pushing—and wins when it matters most.
 The business owner who refuses to accept a scarcity mindset finds creative ways to grow.

The difference?

Belief.

 What’s one belief you’ve had to rewire in order to grow? Drop it in the comments—I’d love to hear your story.

𝐖𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐦𝐲 𝐞𝐱𝐚𝐜𝐭 𝐟𝐫𝐚𝐦𝐞𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐤 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐛𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐡𝐫𝐨𝐮𝐠𝐡 𝐥𝐢𝐦𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐛𝐞𝐥𝐢𝐞𝐟𝐬, 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭 “𝐁𝐄𝐋𝐈𝐄𝐅” 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐈’𝐥𝐥 𝐬𝐞𝐧𝐝 𝐢𝐭 𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫.

Introverts can’t be great leaders.

That’s the myth we have been told for years.

In reality, introverts lead with depth, strategy, and quiet confidence.

As an introvert, these traits make you an incredible leader:

1. Deep Listening Skills
↳ You focus on what’s being said, not who speaks the most.

2. Calm Under Pressure
↳ You stay steady when chaos hits.

3. Self-Reflection
↳ You regularly assess and refine how you lead.

4. Thoughtful Decision-Making
↳ You take time to think before acting, avoiding mistakes.

5. Big-Picture Thinking
↳ You see long-term goals instead of getting lost in the moment.

6. Strong Emotional Awareness
↳ You notice unspoken emotions and team energy.

7. Leading with Authenticity
↳ You don’t fake confidence; you build real trust.

8. Intense Focus
↳ You work through problems without getting sidetracked.

9. Empowering Others
↳ You don’t need to take center stage.

10. Meaningful One-on-One Connections
↳ You create honest conversations that go beyond small talk.

You don’t need to be the loudest to make an impact.

Your quiet leadership speaks for itself.

What else would you add?


Repost to help introverts lead with confidence.
Followfor more.

postsData.content:
Nobody gives a shit about the story you asked ChatGPT to write.

I'm probably the first person to admit that I've used AI the wrong way.

I fell into the trap of convincing myself that I should try mixing authentic content with "viral" content to get followers.

But every time I did I felt like a fraud.

It brought my attention away from my the thoughts and reflections I was having in the real world.

I got caught up in my ego, and addicted to vanity metrics like followers, likes, comments, etc.

And for what?

Going viral doesn’t mean you win.

Because when you go viral for the wrong reasons, you reach the wrong people.

People who don’t actually care about what you have to say.
People driven by fear.
People driven by hate.
People who are not like you.

And that’s the biggest risk: Losing yourself in the pursuit of attention.

So I've made the decision to stick to my guns and be me.

- No more generic, AI-generated quotes.
- No more rewording someone else’s idea to make it mine.
- No more chasing engagement at the cost of authenticity.

From now on I will be Philip.

That's why I started posting here in the first place.

comments.commentText: I have removed 500 old connections last night and will continue cleaning up until I have relevant startup community built. I went viral 3 or 4 times and that kind of didn't help. Follower count is a vanity metric, but money in the bank allows you to buy food and pay bills.
Spending time connecting with people you want to be around and removing those you don't is what makes or breaks this platform.

I have so many times asked ChatGPT to make my posts more adapted for social media/LinkedIn in my case. Every time I feel it’s so bad, so I go back to my original post. ChatGPT removes the personalities from the posts, making them land “flat”. I understand ChatGpT is great for many things, but expressing one’s thoughts, maybe not?

It really is poison. I've been observing how I've felt after doing it in the past, and could just tell how it was pulling me away from myself. I would get confirmation from all the impressions and likes, but once that died down I felt disconnected from myself.

Sandra, indeed, when it comes to writing GPT is great at wasting my time. My process goes like this: I'm fine-tuning my text, then running it through GPT and re-fine-tuning his. The result sucks, so 2 hours later I'm back at polishing the original text

 𝐎𝐛𝐬𝐞𝐫𝐯𝐞 𝐁𝐞𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐘𝐨𝐮 𝐄𝐧𝐠𝐚𝐠𝐞 – Every workplace has its dynamics. Understand the culture, key players, and unspoken rules before making bold moves.

 𝐀𝐝𝐝 𝐕𝐚𝐥𝐮𝐞 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐥𝐲 – Stay where your contributions matter. If your presence is overlooked, reassess if you're in the right place.

postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM – Part 5 – CURATING Agentic Expertise
Multidisciplinary expertise is critical to correctly define the key premises driving problem analysis and solution architecture, and the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem (left image) enables capturing that expertise as a reusable computing asset.

The current AI chaos is due to 70 years of narrow and unexamined premises. The promise of AGI in the 1950s was rooted in premises that have been disproven by real-world evidence but blindly adhered to by those making today’s AGI claims. Key examples:

-Premise: language is the source of intelligence
-Reality: intelligence is the source of language - babies are intelligent before they can speak

-Premise: data is a representation of the real world
-Reality: data is the output of a machine and represents only what the machine was designed to capture

-Premise: the brain constructs objects by identifying frequent patterns of object bits
-Reality: the brain contains networks of abstract concept cells which fire when the concepts are presented in diverse versions and formats (text, image, sound, etc.)

-Premise: neural networks imitate how the brain reasons by processing massive data exhaustively
-Reality: the brain computes the relevance of inputs using inhibition networks, filtering out over 99.99% of sensory data

There are more, but the point is that the main objectives of curation are:
1-Ensure that knowledge from all relevant domains is included in the ontology
2-Map the relevant knowledge concepts across the domains to problem and solution concepts
3-Maintain the landscape concepts (science, business, regulation, etc.) reasonably updated

To enable these objectives, the custodian systems must support:
1-Biomimetic digital twinning of problem and solution concepts
2-Independent update by authorized experts
2-Simulation and testing of the impact of proposed updates across the ontology architecture

The methodology and technology to build this type of biomimetic digital twin ecosystem exist, we have produced published results, and I have discussed this in my posts.

The vision of the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem in the image, however, is in early stages and will require committed partners with the necessary resources who want to participate in shaping the implementation of this new paradigm.
postsData.commentAdded: Exciting insights! Embracing multidisciplinary expertise is key to redefining AI’s trajectory. Looking forward to seeing the evolution of the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem!

postsData.content:
When I first started working with clients, I thought the key to success was simple deliver great work, and they’ll stick around. But over time, I realized something: great work alone isn’t enough.
Clients stay when they trust you. And trust isn’t built through one-off transactions-it’s built through consistency, communication, and genuine care.

Here’s what’s helped me:

 Actually Listen (Not Just Hear)
Early on, I used to jump straight into solutions. But the best client relationships come when you take a step back, really listen, and ask the right questions. Sometimes, what they say they need isn’t actually what they need. Understanding that difference makes all the difference.

 Set Expectations Clearly (and Stick to Them)
Nothing ruins a relationship faster than misaligned expectations. I’ve learned to be upfront about timelines, challenges, and deliverables—because a tough conversation now is better than a tough situation later.

 Be Proactive, Not Just Responsive
The best way to build trust? Solve a problem before they even realize it exists. Whether it’s offering insights, flagging potential roadblocks, or just checking in before they have to ask—it shows you genuinely care about their success.
 Clients Are People, Not Just Accounts
This one is big. At the end of the day, relationships matter more than transactions. A quick check-in, a personal touch, or even just remembering small details about them makes all the difference. The best client relationships feel more like partnerships than contracts.

 Follow-Ups Are Everything
I’ve seen great conversations fade into nothing simply because no one followed up. A quick message, a helpful resource, or just a simple “Hey, how’s everything going?” keeps the connection strong. Clients appreciate knowing they’re more than just a deal.

 Final Thought: Clients don’t leave because of price or even competition most of the time. They leave when they feel unheard, unvalued, or like just another number. Treat them like people, and they’ll stay for the long run.
postsData.commentAdded: Well said! Trust and genuine care truly transform client relationships into lasting partnerships. Listening makes all the difference!

postsData.name:
Dr. Kruti Lehenbauer
Dr. Kruti Lehenbauer
postsData.content:
Do You Know Your ROC?
(Return on Costs)

Yes, I know that
Every dashboard,
Every analytics software,
Every measured metric tool,
Includes something on returns (ROI, usually).

But that is not what I am talking about!
Not everything is an investment in economics.
Investments should meet at least one of these:
1. Borrowed dollars (capital) to fund them.
2. Used previous savings (capital) to fund them.
3. Paying or losing interest ($) on those used funds.

If you are paying for an AI or digital tool
Or for data storage or cloud or cybersecurity
On a subscription (monthly or annual) basis
As a part of ongoing COSTS for your business,
It is NOT an investment but one of the usual costs.
(In economics terms, it most closely resembles "land")

In this example of a very small business:
1. Current Costs = $20K/mth = $240K/year
2. Current Revenues = $45K/mth = $540K/year
3. Current Profits = $25K/mth = $300K/year

If AI/digital subscriptions are obtained at 5K/mth (60K/yr):
1. There might be no big difference in first Quarter.
2. In subsequent quarters, revenues are likely to rise.
3. Increase in annual cost = (300 - 240)/240 = 25%
4. Increase in annual revenue = (765 - 540)/540 = 42%
5. Increase in annual profit = (465 - 300)/300 = 55%

So, how to calculate Returns on Cost?
* Additional new Cost = $60K/yr.
* Returns on Cost for Revenues = (765 - 540)/60 = 375%
* Returns on Cost for Profits = (465 - 300)/60 = 275%

Actionable Insights for SMBs:
1. Make sure to identify the right tools first.
2. Don't jump on to every hype and over commit.
3. Don't delay in making decisions on AI adoption.
4. Consider ROI only if you are "investing" long term.
5. Returns on Costs are easy to measure in short term.
6. Many subscription costs can be reduced very quickly.

Follow&for
insights.

P.S.: Do you use a Returns on Costs equivalent metric?

These 9 books will transform the way you lead.

𝗪𝗵𝘆?
• Leadership goes beyond titles or authority.

Here are 9 books that provide timeless leadership insights:

1. "𝗔𝘁𝗼𝗺𝗶𝗰 𝗛𝗮𝗯𝗶𝘁𝘀" 𝗯𝘆 𝗝𝗮𝗺𝗲𝘀 𝗖𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿
→ Lesson: Your systems determine your success.

Leadership thrives on small, consistent habits that create lasting change, rather than sweeping actions.

2. "𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗙𝗶𝗿𝘀𝘁 90 𝗗𝗮𝘆𝘀" 𝗯𝘆 𝗠𝗶𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗲𝗹 𝗪𝗮𝘁𝗸𝗶𝗻𝘀
→ Lesson: Early wins build trust and momentum.

When starting a leadership role, initial results set the foundation for long-term success.

3. "𝗗𝗿𝗶𝘃𝗲" 𝗯𝘆 𝗗𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗲𝗹 𝗛. 𝗣𝗶𝗻𝗸
→ Lesson: Motivation is fueled by autonomy, mastery, and purpose.

Teams perform their best when they feel empowered and find meaning in their work.

4. "𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗘𝗮𝘁 𝗟𝗮𝘀𝘁" 𝗯𝘆 𝗦𝗶𝗺𝗼𝗻 𝗦𝗶𝗻𝗲𝗸
→ Lesson: Leadership is about prioritizing your people.

Strong leaders create safe environments where teams can thrive and perform their best.

5. "𝗥𝗮𝗱𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗖𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗼𝗿" 𝗯𝘆 𝗞𝗶𝗺 𝗦𝗰𝗼𝘁𝘁
→ Lesson: Honest feedback, delivered with empathy, drives growth.

Leadership involves balancing personal care with constructive challenge.

6. "𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗖𝘂𝗹𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗱𝗲" 𝗯𝘆 𝗗𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗲𝗹 𝗖𝗼𝘆𝗹𝗲
→ Lesson: Strong cultures are built with intention.

Trust, vulnerability, and shared goals create exceptional teams.

7. "𝗗𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗱" 𝗯𝘆 𝗕𝗿𝗲𝗻é 𝗕𝗿𝗼𝘄𝗻
→ Lesson: Courage and vulnerability go hand in hand.

Leaders show up wholeheartedly, even when they don’t have all the answers.

8. "𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗙𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗗𝘆𝘀𝗳𝘂𝗻𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗧𝗲𝗮𝗺" 𝗯𝘆 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗰𝗸 𝗟𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗶
→ Lesson: Trust is the foundation of collaboration.

Teams that trust each other can overcome obstacles and achieve great results.

9. "𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗢𝗯𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗰𝗹𝗲 𝗜𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗪𝗮𝘆" 𝗯𝘆 𝗥𝘆𝗮𝗻 𝗛𝗼𝗹𝗶𝗱𝗮𝘆

postsData.content:
Stop hiring product managers for domain knowledge first!

You heard me right!

Typically, when you hire a product manager, you get two types of candidates that people think of as good... The ones...

... with  deep domain knowledge in your industry

... with  strong product management skillsets

If you are lucky, you can get both together. They are rare, though, so don't wait to find them unless you are in a rush! These unicorns are rare - and even in the current recruiters market the opportunity cost is huge.

The anti-pattern I see is that people hire focused on domain knowledge because the candidates sound knowledgeable about the industry in the interview, and it's easy to assess that as someone embedded in the industry.

Assessing product management skills, on the other hand, is much harder and requires the interviewer(s) to step out of their comfort zone!

In general, if there is one thing you won't be short of in your company is industry knowledge. And a great PM will learn that in very little time from all the other people who are already there. Heck coming in with fresh eyes can also be valuable to question some assumptions!

What is much rarer is strong product management skills.

Hire for strong product management skills, and teach them deep domain knowledge!



——-
Hi, I’m Phil.  My mission is to help product leaders think, make decisions and take action that drives outcomes.

Let’s connect!

️ Like if this resonates
️ Repost for your network
 Follow me to see more posts like this

comments.commentText: Wow half a day networking and away from LinkedIn and this one blew up... I must have struck a cord (or a nerve) time to look through the comments!
Phil Hornby yes you sure did

Phil Hornby - Great take! Apologies for the long answer.

This is a mindset shift that many companies need but hesitate to embrace. The assumption that domain expertise automatically makes someone a great PM is like hiring a race car driver just because they know a lot about engines, when what you really need is someone who knows how to win the race.

Great PMs are like master chefs. You don’t hire them because they know one cuisine inside out - you hire them because they can understand ingredients, balance flavors and create a winning dish no matter what.

Hire a chef who can cook, not just someone who knows your kitchen.

Here’s why:
1) Skill > Domain: A PM who excels at prioritization can triage features for a fintech app just as effectively as for a farming SaaS tool.

2) Fresh Eyes = Fresh Wins: Domain-new PMs often ask “Why can’t we?” instead of “Why shouldn’t we?”

Yes, domain knowledge matters. But product thinking, prioritization, problem-solving and execution? Those are the real game-changers.

postsData.content:
I made a hiring mistake that set us back an entire year. It wasn’t because the person was incompetent—it was because they thought certain tasks were beneath them.

A VP of Sales unwilling to jump on a customer call. A VP of Engineering hesitant to dive into code reviews. A marketing exec too quick to outsource to an agency instead of getting their hands dirty.

It often happens when hiring based on pedigree—big-name companies and impressive resumes—without truly assessing their willingness to operate at the level an early-stage startup demands as they perhaps once did.

That’s why I now rely on “Ego Breaker” interview questions. Simple exercises that mimic the work of an individual contributor on their team:
• A VP of Engineering tackling a simple coding challenge.
• A Head of Sales role-playing an outbound call.
• A VP of Marketing doing some back-of-the-envelope funnel math.

The responses fall into three categories:
1️⃣ They refuse—either because they can’t or because they think it’s below them. 
2️⃣ They try but struggle—showing effort but limited ability.
3️⃣ They dive in and excel—demonstrating both skill and willingness.

I’m not expecting perfection. Unused skills atrophy over time. But in an early-stage startup, the right executive needs the humility and willingness to roll up their sleeves.

Of course, some argue that asking these kinds of questions is unfair—that an executive’s job is to lead, not execute. That these tests don’t reflect the strategic vision, coaching, or scaling expertise a great leader brings. I hear that. But in a startup, there is no room for ivory tower leadership. The best executives I’ve worked with have no problem proving they can do what they ask of their teams.

Are these questions a fair test—or an unnecessary hurdle that drives away top talent?

postsData.content:
Most people suck at storytelling.

They ramble. They over-explain. They bore you to death.
But the best? They make you feel something.

Storytelling isn’t just for writers. It’s how you sell, lead and make people care.

Want to be better? Here are a tip:

Show, don’t tell.

Bad storytellers say: “The client was angry.”

Great storytellers show: “The client slammed his fist on the table, his face red, voice sharp enough to cut glass.”

See the difference? You don’t say someone is mad—you make people feel it.

Details create emotions. Emotions create connections.

How would you describe this building?
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Its all about evoking emotions. Great storytelling transforms dry facts into memorable experiences. Let’s harness that power!

postsData.name:
Reno Perry
Reno Perry
postsData.content:
Ace your next job interview.

10 smart questions to try in your next interview:

1. What types of skills is the team missing that you're looking to fill with a new hire?

↳ Listen for specific skills that align with your strengths and expertise.

2. What metrics or goals will my performance be evaluated against?

↳ Look for clear, measurable goals that you feel confident in achieving.

3. What are the company's current goals, and how does this team work to support hitting those goals?

↳ Pay attention to how well the team's objectives align with the overall company mission.

4. What's the most important thing I should accomplish in the first 90 days?

↳ Ensure that the expectations are realistic and that you have the necessary resources and support to achieve them.

5. Do you expect my main responsibilities in this position to change in the next six months to a year?

↳ Be aware of potential role changes and consider if they align with your career goals.

6. Is there anything I should read that would help me have a shared understanding with my potential future colleagues?

↳ This can provide insight into the company culture and expectations. Take note of any mentioned resources.

7. What do new employees typically find surprising after they start?

↳ Watch out for any red flags or challenges that may not have been apparent earlier.

8. How does the team I'll be part of continue to grow professionally?

↳ Look for opportunities for learning, mentorship, and career development within the team.

9. Where have successful employees moved on to?

↳ Pay attention to the types of roles and companies that successful employees have moved on to, as it can indicate potential career paths.

10. Is there anything I can clarify for you about my qualifications that hasn’t already been addressed?

↳ This is your chance to address any concerns or highlight relevant skills that may not have been discussed earlier.

---

Pro Tips:

- Be as specific as possible:

(Example: Instead of just asking "Where have other successful employees moved on to?" Try "Where have other successful managers on the data team moved on to?")

- Don't ask things that you can easily find with a quick Google search

- Listen carefully to the interviewer's responses and take notes to identify key information and potential red flags

---

 Repost to help someone on their next interview
And follow me for more posts like this.

 P.S. Want to level up your job search? Join my Free Masterclass next week for strategies on how to land competitive $200K-$500K roles:

postsData.content:
Yesterday morning, I ate sh*t.

Not metaphorically.

I literally face-planted on my morning walk—right in front of my neighbors and their very judgmental dogs.

Embarrassment got me thinking about something important for startup founders:

After a fall, act like it never happened and keep going.

4 lessons from falling:

1️⃣ Done > Perfect – Shrink the delta between idea and action. Stop overanalyzing. Launch, learn, iterate.

2️⃣ Talk Less, Listen More – Your customers will tell you what they need if you can zip it long enough to hear.

3️⃣ Speed Wins – Follow up fast, fail fast, adapt fast. Your sense of urgency is a superpower or a massive weakness.

4️⃣ No ≠ Never – Stay and play the long game. A "no" today could be a "lfg" tomorrow.

The best sales leaders trip, face-plant, and still manage to look cool getting back up.

But here’s the real question:
Are you unknowingly making mistakes that are killing your sales?

Most founders are—and they don’t even realize it.

Swipe through my slideshow → 8 things founders and startups are doing wrong (and how to fix them today).

P.S. Yes, I waved when I got up.

Dr. Miro Bada
Dr. Miro Bada
postsData.content:
Watch a great team for an hour.

You'll notice something interesting:

It's not their skills that stand out.
It's not their system.
It's not even their strategy.

It's their energy.

Because without a positive attitude:

↳ Knowledge is just information
↳ Skills are just potential
↳ Experience is just time

The truth?
Your attitude isn't just a mindset - it's the energy that transforms teams and builds winning cultures.

12 principles that transform good leaders into great ones:

1. Believe in yourself
↳ Stop waiting for permission - your gut instinct is usually right, and others are waiting for someone to go first

2. Vulnerability is a strength, not a weakness
↳ The conversations you're afraid to have are the ones your team needs most - open up first

3. See good in others
↳ The talent you spot today becomes the game-changer nobody saw coming tomorrow

4. Tell the truth
↳ Trust isn't built in board rooms, it's built when honesty costs something

5. Courage is about being willing to try
↳ Being scared and being brave feel exactly the same - the only difference is what you do next

6. Happiness is a choice
↳ Your mood isn't just your mood - it's the foundation others build their day on

7. Winning is an attitude
↳ Winners aren't born with more talent - they just punch fear in the face more often

8. Optimists do more
↳ While pessimists are still explaining why it won't work, optimists are already making it happen

9. Be a Goldfish
↳ You can't control what happens, but you can control how long you let it matter - reset like a goldfish

10. All people are different people
↳ Surround yourself with people who think differently - echo chambers kill innovation faster than failure ever could

11. Stay teachable
↳ The moment you become the smartest person in the room is the moment you need a new room

12. Doing the right thing is never the wrong thing
↳ Easy choices, hard life. Hard choices, easy life. Your integrity isn't negotiable

Remember:
Average leaders focus on results.
Great leaders focus on energy.

Your attitude isn't just how you show up.
It's how you transform every room you enter.

postsData.name:
Jean Larkin
Jean Larkin
postsData.content:
If there’s one thing co-founding a company has taught me, it’s this: 

Don't avoid disagreements.

Disagree well.

Disagreements, when handled the right way, can lead to incredible outcomes.

One of the most rewarding aspects of working on my upcoming book—co-authored with my business partner—has been the ability to hash out different opinions and come away with something far stronger than what either of us could have created alone.

Here’s a simple example:

My co-author self-identifies as an optimist.
I do not.

This difference has sparked countless conversations—sometimes over specific word choices or small details that, in reality, are indicators of tone and meaning.

And you know what?

Every time we’ve leaned into these differences, openly hashed them out, and truly listened to each other, the final product has been better.

This experience reminded me of something I practice often: the 3 C’s of Collaborative Disagreements:

1️⃣ Curiosity: Approach disagreements with an open mind. Instead of defending your perspective, ask open-ended and clarifying questions ⇢ seek to understand before sharing or debating.

2️⃣ Clarity: Break down the disagreement. Is it about goals, process, or execution, ask clarifying questions. Looping and checking for understanding helps ensure aligned clarity. Clarity creates focus.

3️⃣ Compromise: Be willing to meet halfway when it strengthens the outcome. There are hills you are willing to die on, but far too often we are disagreeing miles away from those hills — if it isn't deeply important to one or both of you it isn't worth an argument.

Studies support this approach. Research from Harvard Business Review shows that teams with constructive conflict are more likely to innovate and outperform their peers because they embrace diverse perspectives.

Collaboration isn’t about always agreeing—it’s about learning from one another, pushing each other, and letting those different perspectives lead to something greater than the sum of its parts.

The lesson? Disagreements, when approached with curiosity and mutual respect, aren’t roadblocks—they’re opportunities for creativity and innovation.

How do you handle disagreements in your collaborations?

comments.commentText: Well-handled disagreements can spark creativity and lead to stronger outcomes.

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Embracing differing perspectives truly fosters innovation. Curious about how others navigate these conversations!

postsData.content:
My first day at the articleship wasn't that great. 

My first post wasn't that great.

My first collab, a networking call, wasn't great.

My first interview wasn't great.

My first experience of living away from home wasn't good.

But you know what?

Each of these experiences taught me something valuable.
They shaped me into who I am today.

I learned that it's okay to feel uncomfortable. It's part of growing.

Every misstep was a lesson in disguise, showing me that perfection isn't the goal—progress is.

Instead of focusing on mistakes always, I began to celebrate small victories.

And started to practice my skills, knowing improvement comes with time and effort. I learned to be kind to myself and to recognize that it's perfectly fine not to have everything figured out right away.

Success isn't overnight; it comes with consistent efforts for days.

So, here's to the acceptance of the journey with flaws.

After all it's not about being perfect, it's about becoming the best version of ourselves.

- Siddhi Bang

comments.commentText: So true

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely love this mindset, Siddhi! Embracing the journey with all its ups and downs is key to growth. Cheers to progress over perfection!

 Transforming Healthcare with Technology: Ed emphasized the importance of balancing clinical, business, and technical expertise to enhance healthcare delivery, drawing from personal life-saving experiences.

 Addressing Healthcare’s Biggest Challenges: He discussed innovative solutions and partnerships to tackle cost pressures and clinician burnout.

 Delivering Great Experiences & Health Outcomes: Strategies to improve patient experience and empower individuals in their own care were highlighted.
